question: Among adults with 1–4 brain metastases undergoing stereotactic radiosurgery, does adding whole-brain radiotherapy increase the incidence of new intracranial metastases compared with stereotactic radiosurgery alone? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: The 12-month brain tumor recurrence rate was 46.8% in the WBRT + SRS group and 76.4% for SRS alone group (P<.001).
content.source_2: In a multi-institutional analysis, adjunctive WBRT after SRS was associated with a higher incidence of new brain metastases at one year compared with SRS alone, driven by increased distant brain failure (adjusted hazard ratio 1.42, 95% CI 1.10–1.84).
content.source_3: CONCLUSIONS Compared with SRS alone, the use of WBRT plus SRS did not improve survival for patients with 1 to 4 brain metastases, but intracranial relapse occurred considerably more frequently in those who did not receive WBRT.
content.source_4: Among patients with limited brain metastases, early WBRT intensified the occurrence of new parenchymal lesions within 6 months relative to focal therapy alone, despite similar overall control rates.
